2096    /**
2097     *  Repeats the given char {@code repeat} to form a new String. The table
2098     *  below shows the various  result for some argument combinations.<br>
2099     *  <br><code>
2100     *  StringUtils.repeat(&nbsp;'a',&nbsp;0&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;""<br>
2101     *  StringUtils.repeat(&nbsp;'a',&nbsp;3&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;"aaa"<br>
2102     *  StringUtils.repeat(&nbsp;'a',&nbsp;-2&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;""<br>
2103     *  </code>
2104     *
2105     *  @param  c   The character to repeat.
2106     *  @param  repeat  The number of times to repeat {@code c}; a negative
2107     *      value will be treated as zero.
2108     *  @return A new String consisting of the given character repeated
2109     *      {@code repeat} times, or the empty String if {@code repeat} was 0
2110     *      or negative.
2111     *
2112     *  @see String#repeat(int)
2113     *
2114     *  @since 0.0.5
2115     */
2116    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2117    public static final String repeat( final char c, final int repeat )
2118    {
2119        final var retValue = (repeat > 0 ? Character.toString( c ).repeat( repeat ) : EMPTY_STRING).intern();
2120
2121        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2122        return retValue;
2123    }   //  repeat()
2124
2125    /**
2126     *  Repeats the given char {@code repeat}, identified by its code point, to
2127     *  form a new String. The
2128     *  table below shows the various  result for some argument
2129     *  combinations.<br>
2130     *  <br><code>
2131     *  StringUtils.repeat(&nbsp;'a',&nbsp;0&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;""<br>
2132     *  StringUtils.repeat(&nbsp;'a',&nbsp;3&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;"aaa"<br>
2133     *  StringUtils.repeat(&nbsp;'a',&nbsp;-2&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;""<br>
2134     *  </code>
2135     *
2136     *  @param  codePoint   The character to repeat.
2137     *  @param  repeat  The number of times to repeat {@code c}; a negative
2138     *      value will be treated as zero.
2139     *  @return A new String consisting of the given character repeated
2140     *      {@code repeat} times, or the empty String if {@code repeat} was 0
2141     *      or negative, or {@code null} if the code point is invalid.
2142     *
2143     *  @see Character#isValidCodePoint(int)
2144     *  @see String#repeat(int)
2145     *
2146     *  @since 0.0.5
2147     */
2148    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2149    public static final String repeat( final int codePoint, final int repeat )
2150    {
2151        final var retValue = (repeat > 0)
2152            ? isValidCodePoint( codePoint )
2153                ? Character.toString( codePoint ).repeat( repeat ).intern()
2154                : null
2155            : EMPTY_STRING;
2156
2157        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2158        return retValue;
2159    }   //  repeat()
2160
2161    /**
2162     *  Repeats the given String {@code repeat} times to form a new String. The
2163     *  table below shows the various  result for some argument
2164     *  combinations.<br>
2165     *  <br><code>
2166     *  StringUtils.repeat(&nbsp;null,&nbsp;2&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;null<br>
2167     *  StringUtils.repeat(&nbsp;"",&nbsp;0&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;""<br>
2168     *  StringUtils.repeat(&nbsp;"",&nbsp;2&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;""<br>
2169     *  StringUtils.repeat(&nbsp;"a",&nbsp;3&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;"aaa"<br>
2170     *  StringUtils.repeat(&nbsp;"ab",&nbsp;2&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;"abab"<br>
2171     *  StringUtils.repeat(&nbsp;"a",&nbsp;-2&nbsp;)&nbsp;&rArr;&nbsp;""<br>
2172     *  </code>
2173     *
2174     *  @param  s The String to repeat, may be {@code null}.
2175     *  @param repeat   The number of times to repeat {@code str}; a negative
2176     *      value will be treated as zero.
2177     *  @return A new String consisting of the original String repeated,
2178     *      {@code repeat} times, the empty String if {@code repeat} was 0
2179     *      or negative, or {@code null} if the input String was
2180     *      {@code null}, too.
2181     *
2182     *  @see String#repeat(int)
2183     *
2184     *  @since 0.0.5
2185     */
2186    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2187    public static final String repeat( final CharSequence s, final int repeat )
2188    {
2189        final var retValue =
2190            nonNull( s )
2191                ? (repeat > 0) && !s.isEmpty()
2192                    ? s.toString().repeat( repeat )
2193                    : EMPTY_STRING
2194                : null;
2195
2196        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2197        return retValue;
2198    }   //  repeat()
2199
2200    /**
2201     *  Replaces the variables of the form <code>${&lt;<i>name</i>&gt;}</code>
2202     *  in the given String with values from the given maps. The method will
2203     *  try the maps in the given sequence.<br>
2204     *  <br>If no replacement value could be found, the variable will not be
2205     *  replaced at all.<br>
2206     *  <br>If a value from one of the maps contains a variable itself, this
2207     *  will not be replaced.<br>
2208     *  <br>The variables names are case-sensitive.<br>
2209     *  <br>Valid variable name may not contain other characters than the
2210     *  letters from 'a' to 'z' (upper case and lower case), the digits from
2211     *  '0' to '9' and the special characters underscore ('_') and dot ('.'),
2212     *  after an optional prefix character.<br>
2213     *  <br>Allowed prefixes are the tilde ('~'), the slash ('/'), the equal
2214     *  sign ('='), the colon (':'), the percent sign ('%'), and the ampersand
2215     *  ('&amp;').<br>
2216     *  <br>The prefix character is part of the name.<br>
2217     *  <br>Finally, there is the single underscore that is allowed as a
2218     *  special variable.
2219     *
2220     *  @param  text    The text with the variables; may be {@code null}.
2221     *  @param  sources The maps with the replacement values.
2222     *  @return The new text, or {@code null} if the provided value for
2223     *      {@code text} was already {@code null}.
2224     *
2225     *  @see #VARIABLE_PATTERN
2226     *
2227     *  @since 0.0.5
2228     *  @deprecated Use
2229     *      {@link Template#replaceVariable(CharSequence, Map[])}
2230     *      instead.
2231     */
2232    @SafeVarargs
2233    @Deprecated( since = "0.1.0", forRemoval = true )
2234    @API( status = DEPRECATED, since = "0.0.5" )
2235    public static final String replaceVariable( final CharSequence text, final Map<String,? extends Object>... sources )
2236    {
2237        return Template.replaceVariable( text, sources );
2238    }   //  replaceVariable()
2239
2240    /**
2241     *  Replaces the variables of the form <code>${&lt;<i>name</i>&gt;}</code>
2242     *  in the given String with values returned by the given retriever
2243     *  function for the variable name.<br>
2244     *  <br>If no replacement value could be found, the variable will not be
2245     *  replaced at all.<br>
2246     *  <br>If the retriever function returns a value that contains a variable
2247     *  itself, this will not be replaced.<br>
2248     *  <br>The retriever function will be called only once for each variable
2249     *  name; if the text contains the same variable multiple times, it will
2250     *  always be replaced with the same value.<br>
2251     *  <br>The variables names are case-sensitive.<br>
2252     *  <br>Valid variable name may not contain other characters than the
2253     *  letters from 'a' to 'z' (upper case and lower case), the digits from
2254     *  '0' to '9' and the special characters underscore ('_') and dot ('.'),
2255     *  after an optional prefix character.<br>
2256     *  <br>Allowed prefixes are the tilde ('~'), the slash ('/'), the equal
2257     *  sign ('='), the colon (':'), the percent sign ('%'), and the ampersand
2258     *  ('&amp;').<br>
2259     *  <br>The prefix character is part of the name.<br>
2260     *  <br>Finally, there is the single underscore that is allowed as a
2261     *  special variable.
2262     *
2263     *  @param  text    The text with the variables; may be {@code null}.
2264     *  @param  retriever   The function that will retrieve the replacement
2265     *      values for the given variable names.
2266     *  @return The new text, or {@code null} if the provided value for
2267     *      {@code text} was already {@code null}.
2268     *
2269     *  @see #VARIABLE_PATTERN
2270     *
2271     *  @since 0.0.5
2272     *  @deprecated Use
2273     *      {@link Template#replaceVariable(CharSequence, Function)}
2274     *      instead.
2275     */
2276    @Deprecated( since = "0.1.0", forRemoval = true )
2277    @API( status = DEPRECATED, since = "0.0.5" )
2278    public static final String replaceVariable( final CharSequence text, final Function<? super String, Optional<String>> retriever )
2279    {
2280        return Template.replaceVariable( text, retriever );
2281    }   //  replaceVariable()
2282
2283    /**
2284     *  <p>{@summary Splits a String by the given separator character and
2285     *  returns an array of all parts.} In case a separator character is
2286     *  immediately followed by another separator character, an empty String
2287     *  will be placed to the array.</p>
2288     *  <p>Beginning and end of the String are treated as separators, so if the
2289     *  first character of the String is a separator, the returned array will
2290     *  start with an empty String, as it will end with an empty String if the
2291     *  last character is a separator.</p>
2292     *  <p>In case the String is empty, the return value will be an array
2293     *  containing just the empty String. It will not be empty.</p>
2294     *
2295     *  @param  s  The String to split.
2296     *  @param  separator   The separator character.
2297     *  @return The parts of the String.
2298     *
2299     *  @since 0.0.5
2300     */
2301    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2302    public static final String [] splitString( final CharSequence s, final char separator )
2303    {
2304        return splitString( s, (int) separator );
2305    }   //  splitString()

2307    /**
2308     *  <p>{@summary Splits a String by the given separator character,
2309     *  identified by its Unicode code point, and returns an array of all
2310     *  parts.} In case a separator character is immediately followed by
2311     *  another separator character, an empty String will be placed to the
2312     *  array.</p>
2313     *  <p>Beginning and end of the String are treated as separators, so if the
2314     *  first character of the String is a separator, the returned array will
2315     *  start with an empty String, as it will end with an empty String if the
2316     *  last character is a separator.</p>
2317     *  <p>In case the String is empty, the return value will be an array
2318     *  containing just the empty String. It will not be empty.</p>
2319     *
2320     *  @param  s  The String to split.
2321     *  @param  separator   The code point for the separator character.
2322     *  @return The parts of the String.
2323     *
2324     *  @since 0.0.5
2325     */
2326    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2327    public static final String [] splitString( final CharSequence s, final int separator )
2328    {
2329        final var retValue = stream( s, separator ).toArray( String []::new );
2330
2331        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2332        return retValue;
2333    }   //  splitString()

2340     *  <p>Beginning and end of the String are treated as separators, so if the
2341     *  first part of the String equals the separator sequence, the returned
2342     *  array will start with an empty String, as it will end with an empty
2343     *  String if the last part would equal the separator sequence.</p>

2345     *  containing just the empty String. It will not be empty.</p>

2350     *
2351     *  @since 0.0.5
2352     */
2353    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2354    public static final String [] splitString( final CharSequence s, final CharSequence separator )
2355    {
2356        final var retValue = stream( s, separator).toArray( String []::new );

2362    /**
2363     *  <p>{@summary Splits a String by the given separator character and
2364     *  returns an instance of
2365     *  {@link Stream}
2366     *  providing all parts.} In case a separator character is immediately
2367     *  followed by another separator character, an empty String will be put to
2368     *  the {@code Stream}.</p>
2369     *  <p>Beginning and end of the String are treated as separators, so if the
2370     *  first character of the String is a separator, the returned
2371     *  {@code Stream} will start with an empty String, as it will end with an
2372     *  empty String if the last character is a separator.</p>
2373     *  <p>In case the String is empty, the return value will be a
2374     *  {@code Stream} containing just the empty String. It will not be
2375     *  empty.</p>
2376     *
2377     *  @param  s  The String to split.
2378     *  @param  separator   The separator character.
2379     *  @return A {@code Stream} instance with the parts of the String.
2380     *
2381     *  @since 0.0.7
2382     */
2383    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.7" )
2384    public static final Stream<String> stream( final CharSequence s, final char separator )
2385    {
2386        return stream( s, (int) separator );
2387    }   //  stream()
2388
2389    /**
2390     *  <p>{@summary Splits a String by the given separator character, identified by its
2391     *  Unicode code point, and returns a
2392     *  {@link Stream}
2393     *  of all parts.} In case a separator character is immediately followed by
2394     *  another separator char, an empty String will be put to the
2395     *  {@code Stream}.</p>
2396     *  <p>Beginning and end of the String are treated as
2397     *  separators, so if the first character of the String is a separator, the
2398     *  returned {@code Stream} will start with an empty String, as it will end
2399     *  with an empty String if the last character is a separator.</p>
2400     *  <p>In case the String is empty, the return value will be a
2401     *  {@code Stream} containing just the empty String. It will not be
2402     *  empty.</p>
2403     *
2404     *  @param  s  The String to split.
2405     *  @param  separator   The code point for the separator character.
2406     *  @return A {@code Stream} instance with the parts of the String.
2407     *
2408     *  @since 0.0.7
2409     */
2410    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.7" )
2411    public static final Stream<String> stream( final CharSequence s, final int separator )
2412    {
2413        //---* Process the string *--------------------------------------------
2414        final var codepoints = requireNonNullArgument( s, "s" ).codePoints().toArray();
2415        final var builder = Stream.<String>builder();
2416        var begin = -1;
2417        for( var i = 0 ; i < codepoints.length; ++i )
2418        {
2419            if( begin == -1 )
2420            {
2421                begin = i;
2422            }
2423            if( codepoints [ i ] == separator )
2424            {
2425                builder.add( new String( codepoints, begin, i - begin ).intern() );
2426                begin = -1;
2427            }
2428        }
2429
2430        //---* Add the rest *--------------------------------------------------
2431        if( (begin >= 0) && (begin < codepoints.length) )
2432        {
2433            builder.add( new String( codepoints, begin, codepoints.length - begin ).intern() );
2434        }
2435        if( (codepoints.length == 0) || (codepoints [codepoints.length - 1] == separator) )
2436        {
2437            builder.add( EMPTY_STRING );
2438        }
2439
2440        //---* Create the return value *---------------------------------------
2441        final var retValue = builder.build();
2442
2443        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2444        return retValue;
2445    }   //  stream()
2446
2447    /**
2448     *  <p>{@summary Splits a String by the given separator sequence and
2449     *  returns an instance of
2450     *  {@link Stream}
2451     *  containing all parts.} In case a separator sequence is immediately
2452     *  followed by another separator sequence, an empty String will be put to
2453     *  the {@code Stream}.</p>
2454     *  <p>Beginning and end of the String are treated as separators, so if the
2455     *  first part of the String equals the separator sequence, the returned
2456     *  {@code Stream} will start with an empty string, as it will end with an
2457     *  empty String if the last part would equal the separator sequence.</p>
2458     *  <p>In case the String is empty, the return value will be a
2459     *  {@code Stream} containing just the empty String. It will not be
2460     *  empty.</p>
2461     *
2462     *  @param  string  The String to split.
2463     *  @param  separator   The separator sequence.
2464     *  @return The parts of the String.
2465     *
2466     *  @since 0.0.7
2467     */
2468    @SuppressWarnings( "QuestionableName" )
2469    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.7" )
2470    public static final Stream<String> stream( final CharSequence string, final CharSequence separator )
2471    {
2472        //---* Process the string *--------------------------------------------
2473        @SuppressWarnings( "LocalVariableNamingConvention" )
2474        var s = requireNonNullArgument( string, "s" ).toString();
2475        @SuppressWarnings( "LocalVariableNamingConvention" )
2476        final var t = requireNotEmptyArgument( separator, "separator" ).toString();
2477
2478        final var builder = Stream.<String>builder();
2479        var pos = Integer.MAX_VALUE;
2480        while( isNotEmpty( s ) && (pos >= 0) )
2481        {
2482            pos = s.indexOf( t );
2483            switch( Integer.signum( pos ) )
2484            {
2485                case 0 -> /* String starts with separator */
2486                    {
2487                        builder.add( EMPTY_STRING );
2488                        s = s.substring( t.length() );
2489                    }
2490                case 1 -> /* String contains a separator somewhere */
2491                    {
2492                        builder.add( s.substring( 0, pos ) );
2493                        s = s.substring( pos + t.length() );
2494                    }
2495                default -> { /* Just leave the loop */ }
2496            }   //  ResultHandlerSwitch:
2497        }
2498
2499        //---* Add the rest *--------------------------------------------------
2500        builder.add( s );
2501
2502        //---* Create the return value *---------------------------------------
2503        final var retValue = builder.build();
2504
2505        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2506        return retValue;
2507    }   //  stream()
2508
2509    /**
2510     *  <p>{@summary Splits a String using the given regular expression and
2511     *  returns an instance of
2512     *  {@link Stream}
2513     *  providing all parts.} In case a separator sequence is immediately
2514     *  followed by another separator sequence, an empty String will be put to
2515     *  the {@code Stream}.</p>
2516     *  <p>Beginning and end of the String are treated as separators, so if the
2517     *  first part of the String equals the separator sequence, the returned
2518     *  {@code Stream} will start with an empty string, as it will end with an
2519     *  empty String if the last part would equal the separator sequence.</p>
2520     *  <p>In case the String is empty, the return value will be a
2521     *  {@code Stream} containing just the empty String. It will not be
2522     *  empty.</p>
2523     *
2524     *  @note This method behaves different from
2525     *      {@link String#split(String)}
2526     *      as it will return trailing empty Strings.
2527     *
2528     *  @param  s  The String to split.
2529     *  @param  pattern The separator sequence.
2530     *  @return The parts of the String.
2531     *
2532     *  @see String#split(String)
2533     *  @see Pattern#split(CharSequence)
2534     *
2535     *  @since 0.0.7
2536     */
2537    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.7" )
2538    public static final Stream<String> stream( final CharSequence s, final Pattern pattern )
2539    {
2540        requireNonNullArgument( pattern, "pattern" );
2541
2542        //---* Process the string *--------------------------------------------
2543        final var builder = Stream.<String>builder();
2544        if( isEmpty( requireNonNullArgument( s, "s" ) ) )
2545        {
2546            builder.add( EMPTY_STRING );
2547        }
2548        else
2549        {
2550            final var parts = pattern.split( s );
2551            for( final var part : parts )
2552            {
2553                builder.add( part );
2554            }
2555            final var matcher = pattern.matcher( s );
2556            var count = 0;
2557            while( matcher.find() ) ++count;
2558            //noinspection ForLoopWithMissingComponent
2559            for( ; count >= parts.length; --count )
2560            {
2561                builder.add( EMPTY_STRING );
2562            }
2563        }
2564
2565        //---* Create the return value *---------------------------------------
2566        final var retValue = builder.build();
2567
2568        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2569        return retValue;
2570    }   //  stream()
2571
2572    /**
2573     *  Strips HTML or XML tags from the given String, without touching other
2574     *  entities (like {@code &amp;} or {@code &nbsp;}). The result would be
2575     *  the effective text, stripped from all other whitespace (except single
2576     *  blanks).<br>
2577     *  <br>This means that the result for
2578     *  <pre><code>stripTags( &quot;&lt;html&gt;
2579     *      &lt;head&gt;
2580     *        &hellip;
2581     *      &lt;/head&gt;
2582     *      &lt;body&gt;
2583     *        &lt;a href='&hellip;'&gt;       Simple          &lt;br&gt;
2584     *          &lt;br&gt;           Text       &lt;/a&gt;
2585     *      &lt;/body&gt;
2586     *  &lt;/html&gt;&quot; )</code></pre> would be just
2587     *  &quot;{@code Simple Text}&quot;.<br>
2588     *  <br>Comments will be stripped as well, and {@code <pre>} tags are not
2589     *  interpreted, with the consequence that any formatting with whitespace
2590     *  gets lost. {@code CDATA} elements are stripped, too.
2591     *
2592     *  @param  s   The HTML/XML string.
2593     *  @return The string without the tags.
2594     *
2595     *  @since 0.0.7
2596     */
2597    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2598    public static final String stripTags( final CharSequence s )
2599    {
2600        final var retValue = new StringBuilder();
2601        if( isNotEmptyOrBlank( requireNonNullArgument( s, "s" ) ) )
2602        {
2603            final var matcher = m_TagRemovalPattern.matcher( s );
2604            final var buffer = matcher.replaceAll( " " ).trim().codePoints().toArray();
2605            int lastChar = NULL_CHAR;
2606            ScanLoop: for( final var c : buffer )
2607            {
2608                if( isWhitespace( c ) )
2609                {
2610                    //---* Consecutive whitespace detected *-------------------
2611                    if( isWhitespace( lastChar ) ) continue ScanLoop;
2612
2613                    //---* All resulting whitespace have to be blanks *--------
2614                    retValue.append( " " );
2615                }
2616                else
2617                {
2618                    //---* Write the character *-------------------------------
2619                    retValue.append( toChars( c ) );
2620                }
2621                lastChar = c;
2622            }   //  ScanLoop:
2623        }
2624
2625        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2626        return retValue.toString();
2627    }   //  stripTags()
2628
2629    /**
2630     *  <p>{@summary Strips characters from the given input that are not
2631     *  allowed (or should be at least avoided) for a file or folder name on
2632     *  most or all operating systems.}</p>
2633     *  <p>The following characters will be stripped:</p>
2634     *  <dl>
2635     *  <dt><b>:</b> (colon)</dt><dd>On Windows systems it is used to separate
2636     *  the drive letter from the path and file name; on Unix-like operating
2637     *  systems (including MacOS) it would be valid, but it can cause issues on
2638     *  the {@code PATH} and {@code CLASSPATH} variables on these operating
2639     *  systems.</dd>
2640     *  <dt><b>\</b> (backslash)</dt><dd>On Windows systems it is used as the
2641     *  path separator, while on Unix-like operating systems it is problematic
2642     *  in other ways. For example, it is used to escape blanks in not-quoted
2643     *  file or folder names.</dd>
2644     *  <dt><b>/</b> (slash or forward slash)</dt><dd>The path separator on
2645     *  Unix-like operating systems, but Java will use it that way on Windows
2646     *  systems, too.</dd>
2647     *  <dt><b>;</b> (semicolon)</dt><dd>It can cause issues on the {@code PATH}
2648     *  and {@code CLASSPATH} variables on Windows.</dd>
2649     *  <dt><b>*</b> (asterisk)</dt><dd>The asterisk is often used as wild card
2650     *  character in shell programs to find groups of files; using it in a file
2651     *  name can cause funny effects.</dd>
2652     *  <dt><b>?</b> (question mark)</dt><dd>The question mark is used on
2653     *  Windows as a wild card for a single character; similar to the asterisk,
2654     *  it can cause funny effects when used in a file name.</dd>
2655     *  <dt><b>&quot;</b> (double quotes)</dt>
2656     *  <dt><b>'</b> (single quotes)</dt><dd>Both have some potential to
2657     *  confuse the various shell programs of all operating systems.</dd>
2658     *  <dt><b>@</b> ('at'-sign)</dt><dd>Although it is allowed for file and
2659     *  folder names, it causes issues when used in the URL for that respective
2660     *  file.</dd>
2661     *  <dt><b>|</b> (pipe symbol)</dt><dd>Similar to the '*' (asterisk), the
2662     *  pipe-symbol has â as the name already indicates - a meaning on most
2663     *  shells that would make it difficult to manage files that contains this
2664     *  character in their names.</dd>
2665     *  <dt><b>&lt;</b> (less than)</dt>
2666     *  <dt><b>&gt;</b> (greater than)</dt><dd>Like the pipe, these two have a
2667     *  meaning on most shells that would make it difficult to manage files
2668     *  that contains one of these characters in their names.</dd>
2669     *  <dt>Whitespace</dt><dd>Only blanks will remain, any other whitespace
2670     *  characters are stripped.</dd>
2671     *  </dl>
2672     *  <p>Finally, the method will strip all leading and trailing blanks;
2673     *  although blanks are usually allowed, they are confusing when not
2674     *  surrounded by some visible characters.</p>
2675     *  <p>Especially regarding the characters that are critical for shells
2676     *  ('*', '?', '&quot;', ''', '|', '&lt;', and '&gt;') this method is
2677     *  over-cautious, as most shells could handle them after proper escaping
2678     *  the offending characters or quoting the file name.</p>
2679     *  <p>This method furthermore assumes that any other Unicode character is
2680     *  valid for a file or folder name; unfortunately, there are filesystems
2681     *  where this is not true.</p>
2682     *
2683     *  @note   This method will not take care about the length of the returned
2684     *      String; this means the result to a call to this method may still be
2685     *      invalid as a file or folder name because it is too long.
2686     *
2687     *  @param  s   The input String, denoting a file or folder name -
2688     *      <i>not</i> a full path.
2689     *  @return The String without the characters that are invalid for a file
2690     *      name. This value will never be {@code null} or empty.
2691     *  @throws NullArgumentException   The input is {@code null}.
2692     *  @throws EmptyArgumentException  The input is the empty String.
2693     *  @throws ValidationException After stripping the invalid characters the
2694     *      return value would be empty.
2695     *
2696     *  @since 0.0.5
2697     */
2698    @SuppressWarnings( "SwitchStatementWithTooManyBranches" )
2699    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2700    public static final String stripToFilename( final CharSequence s ) throws ValidationException
2701    {
2702        final var len = requireNotEmptyArgument( s, "s" ).length();
2703        final var buffer = new StringBuilder( len );
2704        ScanLoop: for( var i = 0; i < len; ++i )
2705        {
2706            final var currentCharacter = s.charAt( i );
2707            Selector:
2708            //noinspection SwitchStatementWithTooManyBranches
2709            switch( currentCharacter )
2710            {
2711                case ':':
2712                case '\\':
2713                case '/':
2714                case ';':
2715                case '*':
2716                case '"':
2717                case '\'':
2718                case '@':
2719                case '|':
2720                case '?':
2721                case '<':
2722                case '>':
2723                    continue ScanLoop;
2724
2725                default:
2726                {
2727                    if( (currentCharacter == ' ') || (!isISOControl( currentCharacter ) && !isWhitespace( currentCharacter )) )
2728                    {
2729                        buffer.append( currentCharacter );
2730                    }
2731                    break Selector;
2732                }
2733            }   //  Selector:
2734        }   //  ScanLoop:
2735
2736        final var retValue = buffer.toString().trim();
2737        if( retValue.length() < 1 )
2738        {
2739            throw new ValidationException( format( "After stripping the invalid characters from '%1$s' there do not remain enough characters for a valid file name", s.toString() ) );
2740        }
2741
2742        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2743        return retValue;
2744    }   //  stripToFilename()
2745
2746    /**
2747     *  Strips HTML or XML comments from the given String.
2748     *
2749     *  @param  s   The HTML/XML string.
2750     *  @return The string without the comments.
2751     *
2752     *  @since 0.0.5
2753     */
2754    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2755    public static final String stripXMLComments( final CharSequence s )
2756    {
2757        final var matcher = m_CommentRemovalPattern.matcher( requireNonNullArgument( s, "s" ) );
2758        final var retValue = matcher.replaceAll( EMPTY_STRING );
2759
2760        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2761        return retValue;
2762    }   //  stripXMLComments()
2763
2764    /**
2765     *  Translates the given String to a String that will only contain
2766     *  printable ASCII characters; all other characters will be 'escaped' to
2767     *  the format &quot;&#92;uXXXX&quot;.
2768     *
2769     *  @param  s   The input string; may be {@code null}.
2770     *  @return The output string; {@code null} if the input string was
2771     *      already {@code null}.
2772     *
2773     *  @since 0.0.5
2774     *  @deprecated Use instead
2775     *      {@link CharSetUtils#convertUnicodeToASCII(java.text.Normalizer.Form, CharSequence)}
2776     *      with
2777     *      {@link java.text.Normalizer.Form#NFKC}
2778     *      as the first argument.
2779     */
2780    @Deprecated( since = "0.1.0", forRemoval = true )
2781    @API( status = DEPRECATED, since = "0.0.5" )
2782    public static final String toUnicode( final CharSequence s )
2783    {
2784        return CharSetUtils.convertUnicodeToASCII( NFKC, s );
2785    }   //  toUnicode()
2786
2787    /**
2788     *  Changes the first letter of the given String tolower case as per
2789     *  {@link Character#toLowerCase(char)}.
2790     *  No other letters are changed. A {@code null} input String returns
2791     *  {@code null}.<br>
2792     *  <br>Samples:<pre><code>  StringUtils.uncapitalize( null ) = null;
2793     *  StringUtils.uncapitalize(&quot;&quot;)     = &quot;&quot;;
2794     *  StringUtils.uncapitalize(&quot;Cat&quot;)  = &quot;cat&quot;;
2795     *  StringUtils.uncapitalize(&quot;CAT&quot;)  = &quot;cAT&quot;;</code></pre>
2796     *  <br>Basically, this is the complementary method to
2797     *  {@link #capitalize(CharSequence)}.
2798     *  Use this method to normalise the name of bean attributes.
2799     *
2800     *  @param  s   The String to <i>uncapitalise</i>, may be {@code null}.
2801     *  @return The <i>uncapitalised</i> String, {@code null} if the argument
2802     *      was {@code null}.
2803     *  @see #capitalize(CharSequence)
2804     *
2805     *  @since 0.0.5
2806     *  @deprecated Use
2807     *      {@link #decapitalize(CharSequence)}
2808     *      instead.
2809     */
2810    @SuppressWarnings( "DeprecatedIsStillUsed" )
2811    @Deprecated( since = "0.1.0" )
2812    @API( status = DEPRECATED, since = "0.0.5" )
2813    public static final String uncapitalize( final CharSequence s ) { return decapitalize( s ); }
2814
2815    /**
2816     *  Unescapes a string containing entity escapes to a string containing the
2817     *  actual Unicode characters corresponding to the escapes. Supports HTML
2818     *  5.0 entities.<br>
2819     *  <br>For example, the string
2820     *  &quot;&amp;lt;Fran&amp;ccedil;ais&amp;gt;&quot; will become
2821     *  &quot;&lt;Fran&ccedil;ais&gt;&quot;.<br>
2822     *  <br>If an entity is unrecognised, it is left alone, and inserted
2823     *  verbatim into the result string. e.g. &quot;&amp;gt;&amp;zzzz;x&quot;
2824     *  will become &quot;&gt;&amp;zzzz;x&quot;.
2825     *
2826     *  @param  str The {@code String} to unescape, may be {@code null}.
2827     *  @return A new unescaped {@code String}, {@code null} if the given
2828     *      string was already {@code null}.
2829     *
2830     *  @see #escapeHTML(CharSequence)
2831     *  @see #escapeHTML(Appendable,CharSequence)
2832     *
2833     *  @since 0.0.5
2834     */
2835    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2836    public static final String unescapeHTML( final CharSequence str )
2837    {
2838        final var retValue = nonNull( str ) ? HTML50.unescape( str ) : null;
2839
2840        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2841        return retValue;
2842    }   //  unescapeHTML()
2843
2844    /**
2845     *  Unescapes a string containing entity escapes to a string containing the
2846     *  actual Unicode characters corresponding to the escapes and writes it to
2847     *  the given
2848     *  {@link Appendable}.
2849     *  Supports HTML 4.0 entities.<br>
2850     *  <br>For example, the string
2851     *  &quot;&amp;lt;Fran&amp;ccedil;ais&amp;gt;&quot; will become
2852     *  &quot;&lt;Fran&ccedil;ais&gt;&quot;.<br>
2853     *  <br>If an entity is unrecognised, it is left alone, and inserted
2854     *  verbatim into the result string. e.g. &quot;&amp;gt;&amp;zzzz;x&quot;
2855     *  will become &quot;&gt;&amp;zzzz;x&quot;.
2856     *
2857     *  @param  appendable  The appendable receiving the unescaped string.
2858     *  @param  str The {@code String} to unescape, may be {@code null}.
2859     *  @throws NullArgumentException   The appendable is {@code null}.
2860     *  @throws IOException An IOException occurred.
2861     *
2862     *  @see #escapeHTML(CharSequence)
2863     *
2864     *  @since 0.0.5
2865     */
2866    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2867    public static final void unescapeHTML( final Appendable appendable, final CharSequence str ) throws IOException
2868    {
2869        requireNonNullArgument( appendable, "appendable" );
2870
2871        if( nonNull( str ) ) HTML50.unescape( appendable, str );
2872    }   //  unescapeHTML()
2873
2874    /**
2875     *  Parses Strings in the format &quot;<code>&#92;uXXXX</code>&quot;,
2876     *  containing the textual representation of a single Unicode character, to
2877     *  the respective Unicode character. Some Unicode characters will be
2878     *  represented as <i>surrogate pairs</i> in Java, so the String that is
2879     *  returned by this method may contain more than one {@code char}.<br>
2880     *  <br>The input format for this method is used in Java source code
2881     *  Strings, in Java {@code .properties} files, in C/C++ source code, in
2882     *  JavaScript source, &hellip;
2883     *
2884     *  @param  s   The input String with the Unicode escape sequence.
2885     *  @return The Unicode character.
2886     *  @throws ValidationException The input is {@code null}, empty, or cannot
2887     *      be parsed as a unicode escape sequence.
2888     *
2889     *  @since 0.0.5
2890     *  @deprecated Use
2891     *      {@link CharSetUtils#unescapeUnicode(CharSequence)}
2892     *      instead.
2893     */
2894    @SuppressWarnings( "DeprecatedIsStillUsed" )
2895    @Deprecated( since ="0.1.0", forRemoval = true )
2896    @API( status = DEPRECATED, since = "0.0.5" )
2897    public static final String unescapeUnicode( final CharSequence s )
2898    {
2899        return CharSetUtils.unescapeUnicode( s );
2900    }   //  unescapeUnicode()
2901
2902    /**
2903     *  <p>{@summary Unescapes an XML string containing XML entity escapes to a
2904     *  string containing the actual Unicode characters corresponding to the
2905     *  escapes.}</p>
2906     *  <p>If an entity is unrecognised, it is left alone, and inserted
2907     *  verbatim into the result string. e.g. &quot;&amp;gt;&amp;zzzz;x&quot;
2908     *  will become &quot;&gt;&amp;zzzz;x&quot;.</p>
2909     *
2910     *  @param  str The {@code String} to unescape, may be {@code null}.
2911     *  @return A new unescaped {@code String}, {@code null} if the given
2912     *      string was already {@code null}.
2913     *
2914     *  @see #escapeXML(CharSequence)
2915     *  @see #escapeXML(Appendable,CharSequence)
2916     *
2917     *  @since 0.0.5
2918     */
2919    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2920    public static final String unescapeXML( final CharSequence str )
2921    {
2922        final var retValue = nonNull( str ) ? XML.unescape( str ) : null;
2923
2924        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2925        return retValue;
2926    }   //  unescapeXML()
2927
2928    /**
2929     *  <p>{@summary Unescapes an XML String containing XML entity escapes to a
2930     *  String containing the actual Unicode characters corresponding to the
2931     *  escapes and writes it to the given
2932     *  {@link Appendable}.}</p>
2933     *  <p>If an entity is unrecognised, it is left alone, and inserted
2934     *  verbatim into the result string. e.g. &quot;&amp;gt;&amp;zzzz;x&quot;
2935     *  will become &quot;&gt;&amp;zzzz;x&quot;.</p>
2936     *
2937     *  @param  appendable  The appendable receiving the unescaped string.
2938     *  @param  str The {@code String} to unescape, may be {@code null}.
2939     *  @throws NullArgumentException   The writer is {@code null}.
2940     *  @throws IOException An IOException occurred.
2941     *
2942     *  @see #escapeXML(CharSequence)
2943     *
2944     *  @since 0.0.5
2945     */
2946    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2947    public static final void unescapeXML( final Appendable appendable, final CharSequence str ) throws IOException
2948    {
2949        requireNonNullArgument( appendable, "appendable" );
2950
2951        if( nonNull( str ) ) XML.unescape( appendable, str );
2952    }   //  unescapeXML()

2954    /**
2955     *  Returns the Unicode escape sequence for the given character. This will
2956     *  return &quot;&#92;u0075&quot; for the letter 'u', and
2957     *  &quot;&#92;u003c&quot; for the smaller-than sign '&lt;'.
2958     *
2959     *  @param  c   The character.
2960     *  @return The escape sequence.
2961     *
2962     *  @deprecated Use
2963     *      {@link CharSetUtils#escapeCharacter(char)}
2964     *      instead.
2965     *
2966     *  @since 0.0.5
2967     */
2968    @API( status = DEPRECATED, since = "0.0.5" )
2969    @Deprecated( forRemoval = true )
2970    public static final String unicodeEscape( final char c ) { return escapeCharacter( c ); }
2971
2972    /**
2973     *  Returns the Unicode escape sequence for the given code point. This will
2974     *  return &quot;&#92;u0075&quot; for the letter 'u', and
2975     *  &quot;&#92;u003c&quot; for the smaller-than sign '&lt;'.
2976     *
2977     *  @param  codePoint   The character.
2978     *  @return The escape sequence.
2979     *
2980     *  @deprecated Use
2981     *      {@link #escapeUnicode(int)}
2982     *      instead.
2983     *
2984     *  @since 0.0.5
2985     */
2986    @API( status = DEPRECATED, since = "0.0.5" )
2987    @Deprecated( forRemoval = true )
2988    public static final String unicodeEscape( final int codePoint ) { return escapeUnicode( codePoint ); }
2989
2990    /**
2991     *  Returns the given URL encoded String in its decoded form, using the
2992     *  UTF-8 character encoding.<br>
2993     *  <br>Internally, this method and
2994     *  {@link #urlEncode(CharSequence)}
2995     *  make use of the methods from
2996     *  {@link java.net.URLDecoder}
2997     *  and
2998     *  {@link java.net.URLEncoder}, respectively. The methods here were
2999     *  introduced to simplify the handling, as first only the UTF-8 encoding
3000     *  should be used - making the second argument for the methods
3001     *  {@link java.net.URLDecoder#decode(String, String) decode()}/
3002     *  {@link java.net.URLEncoder#encode(String, String) encode()}
3003     *  obsolete - and second, they could throw an
3004     *  {@link UnsupportedEncodingException} - although this should never occur
3005     *  when UTF-8 encoding is used.
3006     *
3007     *  @param  s   The input String.
3008     *  @return The decoded result.
3009     *
3010     *  @see java.net.URLDecoder#decode(String, String)
3011     *
3012     *  @since 0.0.5
3013     */
3014    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
3015    public static final String urlDecode( final CharSequence s )
3016    {
3017        final var retValue = decode( requireNonNullArgument( s, "s" ).toString(), UTF8 );
3018
3019        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
3020        return retValue;
3021    }   //  urlDecode()
3022
3023    /**
3024     *  Returns the given String in its URL encoded form, using the
3025     *  UTF-8 character encoding.
3026     *
3027     *  @param  s   The input String.
3028     *  @return The URL encoded result.
3029     *
3030     *  @see java.net.URLEncoder#encode(String, String)
3031     *  @see #urlDecode(CharSequence)
3032     *
3033     *  @since 0.0.5
3034     */
3035    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
3036    public static final String urlEncode( final CharSequence s )
3037    {
3038        final var retValue = encode( requireNonNullArgument( s, "s" ).toString(), UTF8 );
3039
3040        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
3041        return retValue;
3042    }   //  urlEncode()
3043}
